text:
Hi everyone :wave: Hope you’re having a good start to your week! I’m working on defining different competencies for content roles at our agency, and I was wondering if anyone has any advice/insights/templates for:

• *Content Marketing Specialists vs Strategists* — I’m trying to define the competencies and differences between the roles and what skills/experience levels you need for each.
• For those of you *at agencies, do you have different content roles* other than these? I’m thinking about proposing a Senior Content Strategist role to create a path for after the strategist role.
Thank you so much in advance! :pray:

elements.text: Hope you’re having a good start to your week! I’m working on defining different competencies for content roles at our agency, and I was wondering if anyone has any advice/insights/templates for:
— I’m trying to define the competencies and differences between the roles and what skills/experience levels you need for each.
at agencies, do you have different content roles
other than these? I’m thinking about proposing a Senior Content Strategist role to create a path for after the strategist role.
Thank you so much in advance!

text:
Hi Audrey! I don’t have any templates, unfortunately, and I know this can be pretty nuanced, but here’s been my experience:

• Content Marketing Specialists: These roles are seen a lot in smaller companies that have start-up vibes and can become a bit of a catch-all. BUT, in my experience, the slight differentiator between this and a strategist is this role tends to work alongside digital marketers and demand/lead gen team members. So they are a part of the marketing programming like events, webinars, etc. and can even assist in setting up campaigns. 
• A content strategist is often seen in larger companies with bigger teams and structures and puts in time to help with operational/project management things and can also often work closely with creative teams to help enable wider strategy. 
At the risk of distilling it down too much, I’d say content marketing specialists tend to be focused on the digital marketing world and strategists see and help execute wider scope.
I’ve also noticed that content marketing specialists are often still producers helping set campaigns up and doing a little bit of writing (depending on their skills), and content strategists are not as widely known as producers.

But this is just one woman’s opinion/experience!

Happy to chat more if it will help. :slightly_smiling_face:

A content strategist is often seen in larger companies with bigger teams and structures and puts in time to help with operational/project management things and can also often work closely with creative teams to help enable wider strategy.

At the risk of distilling it down too much, I’d say content marketing specialists tend to be focused on the digital marketing world and strategists see and help execute wider scope.
I’ve also noticed that content marketing specialists are often still producers helping set campaigns up and doing a little bit of writing (depending on their skills), and content strategists are not as widely known as producers.

Happy to chat more if it will help.

text:
Hi <@U012UL77GUT> and thank you so much for your insight! It’s really helpful to get an understanding of the in-house perspective.

My pickle is that I work for a growth marketing agency so all of us are marketers–just different types. We have several content marketing specialists and strategists. Typically each specialist/strategist has a handful of clients they work with and there’s usually a growth marketing specialist/strategist on the client team with them.

So I’m trying to define those roles and create a career development path within an agency, which is a bit tough to do because there aren’t such segmented roles.

elements.text:

text:
Hello friends, sorry in advance for this long narrative. Just want to make the right move and unsure how to proceed. 

I went through 3 interviews for a marketing content writer role, provided several long-form content samples and went through an assignment of editing and writing email, infographic anx landing page copy.

I submitted a Venngage-based infographic "mockup" along with my copy and used the company's corporate colors to try and go the extra mile. I interviewed for a full time permanent role, and now they have posted a contract role for short-form content and occasional long-form.

I submitted my test copy on Thursday, and they posted the contract role that same day. I am quite nervous seeing this temporary posting that maybe they are passing on my candidacy and trying for a contract person instead. They didn't tell me what they thought of my test assignment. Should I ask them about this new contract posting or just wait and see what comes of the permanent role interviews?

The discussions went well and they liked my long form samples. Just don't want to offer to work with them on a contract basis if I am still a viable candidate on a permanent basis. The contract role wasn't offered on their website or to me directly just a new posting on LinkedIn.

It has been a long weekend in Canada, and I am dreading possible bad news tomorrow. Hoping I didn't fail the assignment, and the contract role is just for more capacity. 

Thanks in advance for any thoughts.

elements.text:
Hello friends, sorry in advance for this long narrative. Just want to make the right move and unsure how to proceed. 

I went through 3 interviews for a marketing content writer role, provided several long-form content samples and went through an assignment of editing and writing email, infographic anx landing page copy.

I submitted a Venngage-based infographic "mockup" along with my copy and used the company's corporate colors to try and go the extra mile. I interviewed for a full time permanent role, and now they have posted a contract role for short-form content and occasional long-form.

I submitted my test copy on Thursday, and they posted the contract role that same day. Should I ask them about this new contract posting or just wait and see what comes of the permanent role interviews?

The discussions went well and they liked my long form samples. Just don't want to offer to work with them on a contract basis if I am still a viable candidate on a permanent basis. The contract role wasn't offered on their website or to me directly just a new posting on LinkedIn.

It has been a long weekend in Canada, and I am dreading possible bad news tomorrow. Hoping I didn't fail the assignment, and the contract role is just for more capacity. 

Thanks in advance for any thoughts.

text:
I wouldn’t offer contract until you find out about your current application. companies often have multiple balls in the air, even within the same HR department

there could be many reasons for what you saw. either this is a posting that was in the process of being published that only made it through the system now, or they’re actually looking for a contractor to support whoever they hire full time.

you just don’t know.

if you get rejected (IF), then you can offer to work contract instead. if they like you enough, they may take you up on that offer, and you may end up working full time anyway after they see your worth
